nodes.text: There is not need to exchange blood for oil
Before the first Gulf War two Nobel laureates in economics-Milton Friedman on the right and James Tobin on the left-stated that no war for oil was needed.
Oil accounts for between 65 and 95 percent of the exports of Persian Gulf nations. In contrast oil makes up only about 7 percent of U.S. imports
If economists think that there is no need to exchange blood for oil there is not need to do that
But is the conventional wisdom correct that the United States needs to exchange blood for oil? Many economists don t think so.
The goal is to get the oil from the Persian Gulf countries
The best means to achieve the goal if pacific means are not available is to fight a war against them
Thus most states whether their governments are friendly to the United States or not have a huge incentive to export oil into the world market.
the Persian Gulf countries need to sell oil more than the United States needs to buy it.
Selling oil to U.S. is the best means to fulfil the need to sell oil
